if you haven't read it

a little bit of overview

Fantastic. Well, thank you. Thank you very
much for having me. It's a great pleasure
to be with you all

to talk to you about
a world without work.

And what I want to do is I
want to begin with a story, the great manure
crisis of the 1890s.

And it should have
come as no surprise. For some time in big cities
like London and New York,

the most popular
forms of transport had relied upon horses,
hundreds and thousands of them,

to heave cabs,
carts, wagons, wagons and a whole variety of

And with these horses came

health officer

working in Rochester,
New York calculated that the horses

produced enough to cover an
acre of land to about 175 feet.

So almost as tall as the

at the time extrapolated

from these calculations
to a inescapably manure filled future.

A New York commentator
who predicted that piles of the
stuff would soon reach the height of
third story windows.

A London reporter who said
that by the middle of the 20th century, the streets would
be buried under 9 feet

of the stuff. And it said that policymakers
didn't know what to do. They couldn't simply ban
horses from the street.

They were far too
economically important. But the twist in the
tale is that in the end,

policymakers didn't
need to worry. In the 1870s, the internal
combustion engine was built,

the first. In the 1880s, it was installed
in the first automobile,

later, Henry Ford, of course, brought the Model T

Cars were now a mass thing. By 1912, New York had

Five years after that,

The great manure
crisis was over. So this parable of horse, as

in the New Yorker, has been
told many times over the years-- many times over the years. And in most tellings of the
story, the decline of horses

is cast in an optimistic
light as a tale of technological triumph.

But for this man,
Wassily Leontief, is the Russian
American economist who

would win the Nobel Prize

more unsettling conclusion.

What he saw was how a new
technology, the combustion

engine, had taken an animal
that for millennia had played a central
role in economic life

and had banished it
to the sidelines. And then in a set of
articles in the early 1980s,

he made one of the most infamous
claims in modern economic thought. What technological progress
had done to horses,

he said, it would eventually
do to human beings as well, drive us out of work.

What cars and
tractors were to them, robots and computers
would be to us.

Now, today, the world is gripped
again by Leontiev Sphere. Here in the US
about 30% of workers

believe their jobs
are likely to be replaced by robots and
computers in their lifetime.

In the UK, the same
proportion think it will happen in
the next 25 years.

And what I want to do
today is to explain why I think we need to take
these sorts of fears seriously,

not always their
substance, as we shall see, but I think certain
aspects of their spirit.

Now, will there be enough
well-paid work for everyone to do in the 21st century? I think this is one of the
great questions of our time.

And what I want to
do today is explain why I think we need
to take this threat of technological
unemployment more seriously.

And so in particular,
what I want to do are six different things. The first is I want to set out
just a little bit of the history

of automation anxiety. This isn't the first
time that people have worried about the
impacts of technology on work.

The second is I want to say
a little bit about technology in general. The third is I want to say a
bit more about one technology

in particular, which is
artificial intelligence. It's something that has really
captured people's imaginations

over the last year or so. And I think there
has been some hype

and there has been
some overexcitement. But beneath that, something
interesting has happened. And I want to
spend a bit of time

exploring exactly what
that is, why it matters so much for thinking
about the future of work, and I want to
explain why I think

we need to take these
technological challenges in the world of work seriously. I want to set out a theme that
has become increasingly popular,

few months with respect to technology, that

down, but instead pursue

And I want to share a
few thoughts on that. And then finally,
I want to close with what I think are the
three big problems that we'll

face in a world with less
work, and explain how I think

Economic growth is a
very recent phenomenon. In fact, for most of the 300,000
years that human beings have

been around, economic life
has been relatively stagnant.

But over the last
few hundred years, that economic
activity came, as you can see, to an explosive end.

The amount each person produced

So imagine that the sum of human
existence was an hour long.

Most of this action here

And it was Britain that

as the Industrial
Revolution around the 1760s. And over the following

allowed manufacturers to operate far more
productively than ever

before, in short, to make
far more with far less. And it's here, at the beginning

origins of automation anxiety.

So people start to worry that

as well. The anxiety that automation

Industrial Revolution,

back home,
technological vandalism by the so-called

Destruction of Stockings Frames

Act, et cetera. So destroying machines became

Importantly, though,
this automation anxiety wasn't confined to the
17th and 18th centuries.

It continues right after that

few years, there's been a frenzy of
books and articles

and reports on the
threat of automation. Yet even as early as the 1940s,
the debate about technological

unemployment was so commonplace

it an old argument.

In fact, in almost
every decade since 1920, it's possible to find a piece
in The New York Times engaging

in some way with this threat
of technological unemployment.

And yet, and this
is the key point, and yet most of those anxieties
about the economic harm caused

by these new technologies have
turned out to be misplaced. So looking back over the
last few hundred years,

there's really little evidence
to support that primary fear that technological
progress would

lead to large pools of
permanently displaced people. It's true that workers have been
displaced by new technologies,

but eventually, most have
found new work to do. And so the really
interesting question

is why, Why, in the past,
despite the fears of so many people, did
technological progress not

lead to mass unemployment
as many people worried? And the answer,
when we look back

on what actually happened over
the last few hundred years, is that the harmful effect of
technological progress on work,

the one that really preoccupied
our anxious ancestors, is only one half of the story. So yes, machines took
the place of human beings

in performing certain tasks
and certain activities, but they didn't just
substitute for people.

They also complemented them
at other tasks and activities, the tasks and activities that
hadn't yet been automated,

increasing the demand
for human beings to do those unautomated
tasks instead.

And it's this
helpful force, which is so often forgotten
about, which

works in a variety of different
ways, that, again, increase the demand for
displaced human beings

to do work that hadn't
yet been automated. And this complementing force
works in various different ways,

as I said. And for those who want some
more detail on how it works,

do take a look at the
book A World Without Work. Explore lots of different ways
in which this complementing

force helps increase the
demand for displaced workers. But the key point is this, which
is that distinguishing clearly

between that harmful
substituting force and that helpful
complementing force

helps to explain why those
past anxieties about automation were so often misplaced.

So in the clash between
these two fundamental forces, our ancestors just tended
to pick the wrong winner,

though time and
again, they either neglected that helpful
complementing force altogether, or they imagined
that it would somehow

be overwhelmed by that
harmful substituting force. And that is why they
repeatedly underestimated

the demand for the work of
human beings that would remain. There has always been,
by and large enough

to keep human beings
in employment. So that, I think,
is the context,

turn to think a little
bit about technology. So every day, it
feels like we hear

stories of systems
and machines that are taking on tasks
and activities which until recently, we
thought only human beings alone

could ever do, making
medical diagnoses and driving cars,
drafting legal contracts and designing buildings,
composing music and writing

news reports. Given the time constraints
this afternoon, I just want to focus on the
general way in which I think

about the technological
progress that's taking place at the moment. And I think it's-- although machines can clearly do
more than they can in the past,

they still cannot do everything. There are still clearly limits
to that harmful substituting

force. The problem is that the
boundaries between what these

machines can and cannot do
are unclear and they're always changing.

And so what you see are
lots of books and articles and reports that try to work
out the new limits of machine

capabilities. And they use lots of
different approaches. So one is to try and identify
which particular faculties are

hard to automate. So a popular finding,
for instance, is that new
technologies struggle to perform tasks that
require social intelligence.

So face to face interaction,
empathetic support. So if you look at the
data from 1980 to 2012,

jobs that require a high
level of human interaction grow by about 12% as a
share of the US workforce.

A very different tack
to identifying faculties is to instead look at
the tasks themselves

and ask whether particular tasks
and activities have features that make it more or more easy
or less easy for a machine

to handle them. So if you come
across a task where it's easy to define the
goal, straightforward to tell

whether or not that
goal has been achieved, and there's lots of data
for a system to learn from, then that's the task that
can probably be automated.

And so identifying cats
as a good example of that the goal is simple. Just answer the
question, is this a cat?

It's easy to tell whether the
system has succeeded or not. Yes, that is indeed a cat.

And there are lots
of cats out there on the internet, surprisingly
disturbing number

of cats, apparently 6.5 billion
photos of cats on the internet.

But the obvious
problem with trying to mark out the limits of
machines in either way, either identifying faculties
which are hard to automate

or particular tasks which
are hard to automate, is there any conclusion
that you reach is going to become
outdated pretty quickly?

Those who try to
identify these boundaries are like the proverbial painters
of the Fourth Rail Bridge

in Scotland, a bridge that's
so long they supposedly we

had to start repainting it as
soon as they got to the end, because by that point, the
paint would have already begun

to peel. So you spend too
much time trying to come up with a
sensible account of what

machines can do today. And the chances that
by the time you finish, you're probably going to have
to start again and readjust.

So I think a better way
to think about technology, and this is what
I do in my work, is to try and stop
identifying particular limits,

repress that desire to
want to taxonomize and try to look at the deeper trends.

And I think when you
do that, what you see is that although it's very
difficult to say exactly

what machines will be capable
of doing in the future, I think it's pretty
certain that they're going to be able to do more
than they currently do today.

Now, over time, machines are
gradually, but relentlessly going to take on more
and more of the tasks

and the activities that, at
the moment, only human beings alone could do. Take any technology today.

Look at your laptop,
open your smartphone. That's the worst it's
ever going to be.

And I call this general
trend task encroachment. And when you look at the
three main capabilities

that human beings draw on
when they do their work, whether it's manual
capabilities, so those that involve the
physical world, whether it's

cognitive capabilities that draw
on our capacity for thinking and reasoning, or affective
capabilities, our capacity

for feelings and emotion, what
you see are machines gradually, but relentlessly encroaching
on more and more tasks

and activities that require
each of these capabilities. And if you have a
look at my work,

you'll see hundreds of examples
of this process of task encroachment underway.

I think it's
important, though, just to remember that the examples
that I give in my work

and that some of you will have
read this week on the reading, they're not meant
to be exhaustive. Some impressive
ones are missing,

others, in years to come, will
no doubt look pretty tired. And I think the claims
I'm talking about

aren't meant to be-- I think it's quite important
that the claims that companies talk about are not
taken as gospel either.

I think at times it can be
quite hard to distinguish serious corporate ambitions and
achievements from provocations

drawn up by marketeers whose
job it is to try and exaggerate things. I think the icing
on the cake for me

was when someone
asked at Christmas if I would like an artificially
intelligent toothbrush.

I'm not quite sure
how intelligent you need to be to brush your teeth. But the general point
here is that, if you

dwell for too long on
any particular emission or exaggeration, I think
you're going to miss the bigger

picture here, which is that
these machines are gradually, again, but relentlessly
encroaching

on more and more tasks and
activities that, in the past, required quite a rich range
of human capabilities.

Economists are pretty
wary of labeling any empirical regularity
as a law or as a rule,

but I think this process
of task encroachment has proven to be
almost as law-like

as any historical
phenomenon can be. Barring catastrophe, it seems
pretty likely to continue.

And this, I think, is
the most valuable way to think about
technology in general.

What I want to do
now, though, is just focus on one technology
in particular, which

is artificial intelligence. Because I do think
something really interesting has happened in the field and I
just want to spend a bit of time

setting out exactly
what it is, and that'll help me in explaining
why I think

we need to take these
challenges of automation in the world of
work more seriously. And the story I
want to tell begins

in what I call the first wave
of artificial intelligence. And the first wave took
place in the 1980s.

And the 1980s were
the time when my dad, who was my co-author in writing
the first book that I wrote,

The Future of the Professions,
he was doing his doctorate in artificial intelligence
and the law at Oxford.

So almost 40 years
ago, he was already trying to build systems that
could solve legal problems.

And something really
interesting happened in the UK in 1986, which was that a
very difficult piece of law

was passed called the
Latent Damage Act. And it turned out that
the leading expert

in the world at the time on this
very particular piece of law was a man called Phillip Capper. And Phillip happened to be the
Dean of the law school at Oxford

where my dad was
doing his doctorate. And Phillip came to my dad and
said, look, this is just absurd. Anytime anyone
wants to understand

work together, join forces
and build a system based on my expertise that
people could use instead

of having to come to me? And that's exactly what
they did from 1986 to 1988, they worked on the
development of the world's

first commercially available
AI system in the law.

Now, this was the home screen
design for the system they built. My dad assures me that
this was a cool screen design

in the 1980s. Never been entirely
convinced of that. Just to give you a flavor
of what they are up against,

here's an extract from the law. Section 2 of this act shall
not apply to an action to which this section applies.

It's a more readily
understandable piece of the law. I love this, though. They published it in
the form of floppy disks

at a time when floppy disks
genuinely were still floppy.

And essentially, what
they did together was they built an absolutely
gigantic decision tree, where

you answered these
yes or no questions and you navigated
through a tree that

had quite literally
millions of branches through it that my
dad and his colleagues had manually painstakingly
crafted together

in the computer science lab. Now, what's interesting
is that they

weren't just doing this in law. This was the general
approach in AI back then. And in the beginning,
most people, like my dad,

most AI researchers believe
that building a machine to perform a given
task meant observing

how a human being perform that
task and then copying them. So some people tried
to replicate the actual

structure of the human brain. Others took a more
psychological approach and tried to replicate the
thinking and reasoning processes

that a human being
appeared to be engaged in. A third thing was
to try and draw out the rules that human
beings seem to follow.

But in all these
different efforts, human beings provided the
template for machine behavior

in one way or another. What's interesting is that
ultimately this approach of building machines in
the image of human beings

didn't really succeed. And despite that kind of initial
burst of optimism and enthusiasm

in the 1980s, there wasn't
really a lot of serious progress in artificial intelligence.

And as many of you would know,
as the 1980s came to an end and as the 1990s began
research interest, funding,

basically progress in artificial
intelligence dried up. And a period known
as the AI winter

began where not a lot of
progress happened in the field at all.

And that first wave of
artificial intelligence that had raised so many hopes
ended really in failure.

The turning point comes in 1997. And it's a moment that
I think lots of you will be familiar with. And this is, of course, when
Garry Kasparov, who at the time

was the World
Chess champion, was beaten by a system called Deep
Blue, and it was owned by IBM.

Now, what's really interesting
about this is that if you had gone back to the 1980s and said
to my dad and his colleagues,

do you think something like
this will ever be possible, and remember, they were some
of the most open-minded, they were some of
the most ambitious,

progressive people thinking
about AI back then, if you had said, do you think
something like this will ever be possible, they would have
said to you emphatically, no,

we will never do it. And the reason why they would
have said no is very important. The reason why they would have
said no is because at the time,

they were of that
first wave mindset. So they thought,
again, the only way to build a system to
outperform a human expert

is to sit down with
a human expert, get that human expert to explain
to you how they solve whatever problem it is you're
trying to solve,

and then try and capture
that human explanation in a set of instructions or
rules for a system to follow.

But here's the problem,

of this problem, if you sit down with
Kasparov and say, look, tell

me how it is you're
so good at chess, he might be able to give
you a few clever opening moves or closing plays.

And chess fans in
the room will know that's what he does in his books
and online tutorials and so on. But in the end, he'd struggle.

He'd say things like, it
requires gut reaction, instinct, intuition, judgment,
creativity, instinct, and so on.

In short, he would say, I cannot
articulate to you exactly how it is that I'm so good at chess.

And that was why my
dad and his colleagues thought something like this
could never be automated. If a human being cannot
articulate how they perform

a task, well, where
on Earth do we begin? They worried in writing a set
of instructions for a machine

to follow. Now, what they hadn't banked
on, the mistake that they made was not to anticipate
the extraordinary growth

in processing power that would
happen in the decades to come. So I'm using here an index
of computations per second

as a measure of
processing power. Not a lot happening
between 1850 and 1950.

Only in 1950 you get what

processing power. Of course, though, this
is not a linear increase

in processing power. The y-axis there is

in computational power.

What you're looking at
is an explosive growth in processing power. And this is what my dad and
his colleagues just did not

anticipate back in the 1980s. So by the time that
Garry Kasparov actually sits down with Deep
Blue, and remember,

this is more than 25
years ago, Deep Blue is already calculating up to
330 million moves a second.

Now, Garry Kasparov at
best could juggle 110 moves in his head on any one turn. He was blown out of the water
by brute force processing

power and a huge amount of
data storage capability. It didn't matter. And this is the key
point, it did not

matter that Garry Kasparov
couldn't articulate how he was so good at chess. It didn't matter the
system was able to perform

the task in a fundamentally
different way. It didn't need to replicate
his thinking process or mimic

his reasoning. So this Deep Blue result
was a practical victory, but it was also an
ideological triumph as well.

We can think of
most AI researchers up until that moment as purists,
closely observing human beings

acting intelligently and trying
to build machines like them. But that was not how
Deep Blue was designed.

Its creators didn't set out to
copy the anatomy of human chess players, the reasoning
they engaged in,

or the particular strategies
that they followed. Rather, they were pragmatists. They took a task that
required intelligence

when performed by a human
being and built a machine to perform it in a
fundamentally different way.

And that is what, in my view,
brought artificial intelligence out of its winter. It's what I call the
pragmatist revolution.

And a generation
of systems have now been built in this
pragmatist spirit, crafted to function very differently
from human beings,

judged not by how
they perform a task, but by how well they perform it.

So advances in machine
translation, as many of you will know, have not come
from developing a system that

mimics a talented translator,
but have come from companies scanning millions of human
translated pieces of text

to figure out correspondences
and patterns on their own. Likewise, machines have
learnt to classify images not

by mimicking human vision or
reviewing millions of previously labeled photos--

sorry, not by
mimicking human vision, but by reviewing millions of
previously labeled photos,

hunting for similarities
between those and the particular
photo in the question.

And this is interesting from
a practical point of view and from an economic
point of view, because one of the things
I'm really interested in

is how the economic
literature has, in my view,

systematically underestimated
the capabilities of machines. So what are the tasks
of driving a car,

making a medical
diagnosis, or identifying a bird at a fleeting
glimpse have in common?

Well, these are all tasks that
at one point leading economists, and until very recently,
leading economists

said could not
readily be automated and yet today, all
of them can be.

Almost all major
car manufacturers have driverless car programs,
countless systems that can diagnose medical
problems, and there's even

an app developed by the Cornell
Laboratory of Ornithology that can tell you what a bird
is at a fleeting glimpse.

So what went wrong? These economists were
purists believing

that machines had to copy the
way that human beings think and reason to outperform them.

Now, when they were
trying to determine which tasks machines
could not do, they imagined that the
only way to get a machine

to perform a task was to
sit down with a human being, get him or her to explain
how they perform that task,

and then write a
set of instructions based on that human explanation
for machines to follow. And because most human
beings find it so difficult

to explain how they
do these things, the thought was that
these sorts of things couldn't be automated either.

And it leads, I think, to one
of the most important ideas in my work, and one of
the most important ideas I want to share
today, which is what

I call this artificial
intelligence fallacy. And you see it in lots
of popular commentary

on the future of work, but
also more expert analysis too. And it's the mistaken
assumption that the only way

to develop systems
that perform tasks at the level of human
beings or higher is to somehow copy the way that
human beings perform that task.

Now, that might have been true
40 years ago in that first wave of artificial intelligence, but
it simply no longer the case.

So let me give you
a practical example. And, if I were talking to an
audience of professionals,

doctors, lawyers,
accountants, architects, they'd say, look, Daniel,
that's all very interesting, but you don't understand.

What I do in my work
requires judgment, OK? And judgment is the sort of
thing a machine can never do.

And I say this question, can a
machine ever exercise judgment? It's the wrong
question to be asking

in light of these
technological developments that I've just described. In fact, there are two
more important questions.

The first is this,
to what problem is judgment the solution? Why do people go to doctors
or lawyers or accountants

or architects or whoever
it might be and say, look, I need your judgment,
give me your judgment?

And the answer to that
question, it seems to me, is because of uncertainty. When the facts are unclear, when
the information is ambiguous

and people don't
know what to do, they go to their fellow
human beings and say, look, I need your judgment, perhaps
based on your experience,

to help me make sense
of this uncertainty. So really, the question
we should be asking, the interesting question,
isn't can a machine ever

exercise judgment, but it's, can
a machine deal with uncertainty better than a human being can?

And the answer to that question,
as many of you will know, is of course they can. That is precisely what
they're so good at doing.

They can handle far larger
bodies of data than us and make sense of it in
ways that we, acting alone,

simply couldn't perceive. So a good example of this are
the medical diagnostic systems

that have been developed
in the last few years. This is the one
developed at Stanford that can tell you whether or
not a freckle is cancerous

as accurately as
leading dermatologists. How does it work? It's not trying to copy the
judgment of a human doctor.

It knows it understands
absolutely nothing about medicine at all. Instead, it's got a database
of 140,000 odd past cases,

and again, it's running a
pattern recognition algorithm through those cases, hunting
for similarities between them

and the particular photo of the
troubling freckle in question. It's performing, once again,
the task in an unhuman way.

And it doesn't matter,
and this is the key point, that a human doctor might
struggle to articulate how

they make a medical diagnosis. That inability of
human beings to explain how they do very tricky,
subtle, complex things turns out

to be far less of a
bottleneck on automation than many people thought
was possible in the past.

Can machines think? I love the question from a
philosophical point of view, but from a more
practical point of view,
